  • News

Hubble celebrates 25 years in space

Ebony C. Fleming, Houston Chronicle | January 6, 2015 | Updated: January 6, 2015 6:18pm
  • Comments
  • E-mail
  • Print
  • Tweet
Page 1 of 1
  •  
  • Photo By HubbleSite 
    M16, Eagle Nebula 1995 vs. 2015

    The photo on the left was taken in 1995. It revealed never-before-seen details of three giant columns of cold gas from a cluster of massive stars
    The photo on the right is a recent photo of the Nebulain celebration of its upcoming 25th anniversary of orbit. light.

    Source: HubbleSite
  • Photo By HubbleSite 
    This photo was released for Hubbles 20th anniversary. These pillars show the telltale signature of new stars forming.

    Source:HubbleSite
  • Photo By HubbleSite 
    The Horsehead Nebula is a dense cloud of gas and dust in a much larger structure.

    Source:HubbleSite
  • Photo By HubbleSite 
    Estimated to be 100 times more massive than our Sun, unstable star Eta Carinae may be one of the most massive stars in our galaxy.

    Source:HubbleSite
  • Photo By ESA, Hubble, NASA 
    This view, captured by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, shows a nearby spiral galaxy known as NGC 1433.

    Source:HubbleSite
  • Photo By Universal History Archive/NASA 
    The Antennae galaxies, located about 62 million light-years from Earth, are shown in this composite image.


  • Photo By NASA, ESA, and E. Sabbi 
    NASA's Hubble Space Telescope uncovers a dazzling new view deep inside the Tarantula Nebula. Hubble reveals a glittering treasure trove of more than 800,000 stars and protostars embedded inside the nebula.
  • Photo By Universal History Archive/NASA 
    This NASA Hubble Space Telescope image shows the distribution of dark matter in the center of the giant galaxy cluster Abell 1689, containing about 1,000 galaxies and trillions of stars.
  • Photo By NASA, ESA, A. Goobar (Stockholm University), and the Hubble Heritage Team 
    This is a Hubble Space Telescope composite image of a supernova explosion designated SN 2014J in the galaxy M82. At a distance of approximately 11.5 million light-years from Earth it is the closest supernova of its type discovered in the past few decades.
  • Photo By Universal History Archive/NASA 
    This composite of 30 Doradus, aka the Tarantula Nebula, contains data from Chandra, Hubble, and Spitzer.
  • Photo By NASA, CXC, JPL-Caltech, STScI, NSF, NRAO, VLA 
    Anomalous arms are seen in this composite image of NGC 4258 from NASA's Chandra X-ray Observator.
  • Photo By NASA, ESA, Hubble Heritage Team 
    In celebration of the 24th anniversary of the launch of NASA's Hubble Space Telescope (on April 24, 1990) astronomers took an infrared-light portrait of a roiling region of starbirth located 6,400 light-years away.
  • Photo By NASA, ESA, Hubble Heritage Team 
    Spiral galaxy M83, also known as the Southern Pinwheel, lies 15 million light-years away in the constellation Hydra.
  • Photo By HubbleSite 
    Stellar Spire in the Eagle Nebula is a billowing tower of cold gas and dust rising from a stellar nursery called the Eagle Nebula. The soaring tower is 9.5 light-years or about 57 trillion miles high, about twice the distance from our Sun to the next nearest star.

    Source:HubbleSite
  • Photo By HubbleSite 
    The dark band across the center of theSombrero Galaxyis the result ofmaterial in the flat disk of the galaxy obscuring the light of stars and gas behind it.

    Source:HubbleSite
  • Photo By HubbleSite 
    Titanic gravitational forces rip apart entire galaxies and they fall back together, forming completely different structures.

    Source:HubbleSite

This year makes 25 years since the Hubble telescope was sent into outer space to explore the unknown. 

To mark the milestone, Hubble snapped the image above - a high-definition version of a view of the Eagle Nebula's Pillars of Creation. It's a new look at the iconic image sent back to Earth in 1995. 

But these are just two of the stunning photos the telescope has sent back over the past two decades. Check out the slideshow above to see more of what is beyond our galaxy.

Ebony C. Fleming, Houston Chronicle
